findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop the transactions for all users. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `pause` function.

findings.title: BC - Blacklists Addresses
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to stop addresses from transactions. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `blacklistAddress` function.

findings.title: MEM - Missing Error Messages
findings.description: The contract is missing error messages for the `require` function, making it difficult to identify and fix the issue.

findings.title: IBC - Invalid Blacklist Condition
findings.description: The contract implements a blacklist functionality but checks if the `msg.sender` is blacklisted instead of checking the `_from` and `_to` addresses.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide is a set of guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code. Adhering to a style guide can help improve the readability and maintainability of the Solidity code, making it easier for others to understand and work with.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: Boolean equality is unnecessary when comparing two boolean values.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured by user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems during execution.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
